title: Hot and Sweet Chicken
ingredients: 1½ cups peeled and sliced Golden Delicious apples
2 teaspoons arrowroot (you can substitute cornstarch for arrowroot)
2 cups diced cooked boneless, skinless, chicken breasts
instructions: Before starting combine the fat-free half-and-half and the coconut extract; mix well and set aside.

Heat the canola oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium heat; when the oil is hot, add the apples and the onions.  Sauté the apples and onions for 2 to 3 minutes then add the brown sugar and the “garam masala.”  Stir the mixture well and add the half-and-half mixture, stir to mix well and cover.  Allow this mixture to simmer for 5 minutes.

Remove about ¼-cup of the liquid from the skillet and into it add the arrowroot.  Stir to dissolve the arrowroot in the liquid.  Pour the arrowroot mixture back into the skillet; stir to mix well, and then add the cooked chicken.  Cook, uncovered, for an additional 5 minutes; or, until the sauce is slightly thickened and the chicken is well heated through.
remarks: garam masala [gah-RAHM mah-SAH-lah] Garam is the Indian word for "warm" or "hot," and this blend of dry-roasted, ground spices from the colder climes of northern India adds a sense of "warmth" to both palate and spirit. There are as many variations of garam masala (which may contain up to 12 spices) as there are Indian cooks. It can include black pepper, cinnamon, cloves, coriander, cumin, cardamom, dried chiles, fennel, mace, nutmeg and other spices. Garam masala may be purchased in Indian markets and in the gourmet section of some supermarkets. It's also easily prepared at home, but should be made in small batches to retain its freshness. As with all spices, it should be stored in a cool, dry place for no more than 6 months. Garam masala is usually either added to a dish toward the end of cooking or sprinkled over the surface just before serving.
source: Chicken Leftovers Get Hot and Sweet, Dining Section,  Express-News, Wednesday, February 14, 2007.
